title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #993: Unimodal Independent Sets in Trees**

The sequence (i_0, i_1, i_2, ...) where i_k counts independent sets of size k is unimodal for trees/forests (increases then decreases).

Contrasts with general graphs where ANY pattern is achievable (AEMS 1987).
mathContext: Graph theory: independent sets, unimodality, polynomial methods.

title: Independent Set
content:
**IsIndependentSet S:** No edges between any two vertices in S.

S is independent ⟺ ∀ u, v ∈ S, u ≠ v → ¬(u ~ v)

Independent sets are also called stable sets.

title: Independent Set Count
content:
**indepCount k:** i_k(G) = number of independent sets of size k in G.

i_0(G) = 1 (empty set)
i_1(G) = |V| (all singletons)
i_k(G) = 0 for k > α(G)

title: Independence Polynomial
content:
**independencePolynomial:** I(G, x) = Σ_k i_k(G) · x^k

The generating function for independent set counts. Real-rootedness of this polynomial implies unimodality of coefficients.

title: Unimodal Sequence
content:
**IsUnimodal f n:** The sequence f(0), f(1), ..., f(n) increases then decreases.

Formally: ∃ m ≤ n such that:
- f(0) ≤ f(1) ≤ ... ≤ f(m)
- f(m) ≥ f(m+1) ≥ ... ≥ f(n)

title: Tree
content:
**IsTree G:** G is connected and acyclic.

Equivalently: connected graph with |V| - 1 edges, or unique path between any two vertices.

title: Forest
content:
**IsForest G:** G is acyclic (may be disconnected).

A forest is a disjoint union of trees. Every tree is a forest.

title: Trees are Unimodal
content:
**tree_unimodal:**

For any tree T, the sequence (i_0(T), i_1(T), ...) is unimodal.

This is the main result of Erdős Problem #993.

title: Forests are Unimodal
content:
**forest_unimodal:**

For any forest F, the independent set sequence is unimodal.

Since a forest is a disjoint union of trees, this follows from the tree case.

title: General Graphs Not Unimodal
content:
**general_graph_not_unimodal:**

There exist graphs whose independent set sequence is NOT unimodal.

In fact, AEMS (1987) showed every pattern is achievable.

title: Matching
content:
**IsMatching M:** A set of edges with no shared vertices.

The matching sequence (m_0, m_1, ...) counts matchings by size.

title: Schwenk's Theorem (1981)
content:
**schwenk_matching_unimodal:**

The matching sequence is unimodal for ANY graph.

Contrasts with independent sets, which are only unimodal for special classes like trees.

title: Trees Have Real Roots
content:
**tree_indep_poly_real_roots:**

The independence polynomial of a tree has all REAL roots.

This algebraic property is the key to proving unimodality.

title: Path P_3 Example
content:
**path3_unimodal:**

For P_3 (three vertices in a line):
i_0 = 1, i_1 = 3, i_2 = 1

Sequence: 1 ≤ 3 ≥ 1 ✓ unimodal

title: Log-Concavity
content:
**IsLogConcave f n:** i_k² ≥ i_{k-1} · i_{k+1} for all k.

Log-concavity is STRONGER than unimodality. For positive sequences, log-concave ⟹ unimodal.

title: Fibonacci Numbers
content:
**fib n:** The Fibonacci sequence (0, 1, 1, 2, 3, 5, 8, ...).

For path graphs P_n, the total number of independent sets is F_{n+2}.

title: Independence Number
content:
**independenceNumber G:** α(G) = max{|S| : S is independent}

For k > α(G), we have i_k(G) = 0. The peak of the unimodal sequence is ≤ α(G).

title: Main Summary
content:
**erdos_993_summary:**

- Trees: YES, unimodal ✓
- Forests: YES, unimodal ✓
- General graphs: NO, any pattern possible

Proved using real-rootedness of independence polynomial.

title: Main Theorem
content:
**erdos_993:**

Erdős Problem #993 is SOLVED.

The independent set sequence of any tree or forest is unimodal.
